Debra C. Roberts (South Africa), Renée van Diemen (Netherlands), Phil Williamson (United Kingdom), Panmao Zhai (China)

Annex I: Glossary

This annex should be cited as: IPCC, 2019: Annex I: Glossary [Weyer, N.M. (ed.)]. In: IPCC Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate [H.-O. Pörtner, D.C. Roberts, V. Masson-Delmotte, P. Zhai, M. Tignor, E. Poloczanska, K. Mintenbeck, A. Alegría, M. Nicolai, A. Okem, J. Petzold, B. Rama, N.M. Weyer (eds.)]. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK and New York, NY, USA, pp. 677–702. https://doi.org/10.1017/9781009157964.010

Annex I Glossary

Ablation (of glaciers, ice sheets, or snow cover)
Ablation refers to the reduction in mass of a glacier, ice sheet, or snow cover due to various processes, including melting, calving, sublimation, and loss of wind-blown snow.

Abrupt climate change
Abrupt climate change refers to a large-scale change in the climate system that occurs over a few decades or less, persists for at least a few decades, and causes substantial disruptions in human and natural systems.

Accumulation (of glaciers, ice sheets, or snow cover)
Accumulation refers to the processes that add to the mass of a glacier, ice sheet, or snow cover, primarily through snowfall, as well as deposition of hoar, freezing rain, and other types of solid precipitation.

Active layer
The active layer is the layer of ground above permafrost that is subject to annual thawing and freezing.

Adaptability
See Adaptive capacity.

Adaptation
In human systems, adaptation refers to the process of adjusting to actual or expected climate and its effects to moderate harm or exploit beneficial opportunities. In natural systems, adaptation occurs in response to actual climate and its effects, with human intervention potentially facilitating adjustment to expected climate and its effects.

Ecosystem-based Adaptation (EbA)
Ecosystem-based adaptation involves using ecosystem management activities to increase resilience and reduce vulnerability to climate change.

Evolutionary adaptation
Evolutionary adaptation occurs when a species or population becomes better suited to a changing environment through the selection of heritable traits.

Incremental adaptation
Incremental adaptation involves maintaining the essence and integrity of a system or process at a given scale, often through extensions of actions and behaviors that reduce losses or enhance benefits from natural variations in extreme weather or climate events.

Transformational adaptation
Transformational adaptation involves changing the fundamental attributes of a social-ecological system in anticipation of climate change and its impacts, often requiring system-wide change or changes across multiple systems.

Adaptation limits
Adaptation limits refer to the point at which an actor's objectives (or system needs) cannot be secured from intolerable risks through adaptive actions. A hard adaptation limit is reached when no adaptive actions can avoid the risk.
